Visible Bladder Exposure

The bladder mucosa is exposed on the lower abdomen, typically above the pubic symphysis, and can range from the exposed trigone to the entire bladder.

questions.text: Which of the following finding is seen in toxocariasis?
Second Leopold grip is used for finding position of?
questions.explanation:
Leopold's Maneuver

Position

Technique

Purpose

Fundal Grip (First Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Palpate the fundal area with both hands

Determine which fetal pole is in the fundus

  • Broad, soft, irregular mass: Breech

  • Smooth, hard, globular mass: Head

  • Transverse lie: Neither pole palpable

Lateral or Umbilical Grip (Second Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place hands flat on either side of the umbilicus, palpate one side at a time

Identify the position of the fetal back, limbs, and anterior shoulder

  • Back: Smooth, curved, resistant

  • Limb side: Comparatively empty with small, knob-like parts

  • Anterior shoulder: Prominent in the lower part of the uterus above the head

Pawlik’s Grip (Third Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place thumb and four fingers over the lower pole of the uterus, ulnar border on the upper symphysis pubis

Grasp the presenting part if not engaged and test its mobility

  • Transverse lie: Pawlik’s grip is empty

Pelvic Grip (Fourth Leopold)

Facing the patient’s feet

Place four fingers of both hands on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus, pressing downward and backward

Identify the part in the lower pole, its attitude, and engagement

  • Head Characteristics

    • Precise presenting area

    • Attitude (position of sinciput and occiput)

    • Engagement (noted by the presence/absence of sinciput and occiput, convergence/divergence of finger tips)

questions.text: Non-union of metanephros and ureteric bud components will form which of the following defects:
questions.explanation:
Condition

Description

Image

Horseshoe kidney

(Option A)

A congenital condition where the lower poles of the two kidneys fuse, forming a U-shaped structure, usually without affecting the ureteric bud–metanephros union.

​

Polycystic Kidney Disease

(Option B)

Results from a failure of proper union between the ureteric bud and metanephric tubules, leading to cyst formation due to disconnected nephrons.

​

Duplex Kidney

(Option C)

Caused by duplication of the ureteric bud, resulting in a kidney with two separate collecting systems or ureters.

​

Unilateral Renal agenesis

(Option D)

Occurs when the ureteric bud fails to form or reach the metanephric blastema, leading to complete absence of one kidney.

​

Brighton Criteria for Diagnosis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

Clinical case definitions for diagnosis of GBS

Level 1 of diagnostic certainty

Bilateral AND flaccid weakness of the limbs

       AND

Decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes in weak limbs

      AND

Monophasic illness pattern and interval between outset and nadir of weakness between 12 h and 28 days and subsequent clinical plateau

      AND

Electrophysiologic findings consistent with GBS

     AND

Cytoalbuminologic dissociation (i.e, elevation of CSF protein level above laboratory normal value AND CSF total white cell count <5l cells/ipl

Absence of an identified alternative diagnosis for weakness

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a soft, fluctuant swelling located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle at the junction of the upper and middle thirds. The swelling is non-tender, transilluminates, and has no discharge. Which of the following is not correct about the swelling shown?

options.label: A
options.text: Incomplete obliteration of 2 nd branchial cleft

options.label: B
options.text: Derived from cervical sinus of his

questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Incomplete obliteration of 2nd branchial cleft (fluid-filled cysts) (Option A ruled out)
  • Lined with squamous epithelium.
  • Filled with thick, cloudy fluid.

Appearance & Location
  • Typical Location: Front edge of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (where upper and middle thirds meet).
  • Onset: Early or middle adulthood.
  • Appearance: Soft, sometimes translucent swelling.

Complications
  • Infection: May cause redness, tenderness, and difficulty in distinguishing from other neck masses.
  • Age Consideration: In individuals over 35, rule out cancerous lymph nodes before surgical removal.

Treatment
  • Preferred Treatment: Complete removal, ideally when not infected.
  • Surgical Considerations: Cyst located above hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves, but beneath the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. The spinal accessory nerve must also be identified to avoid damage.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with seizures, irritability, and developmental delay. Blood glucose is normal, but CSF glucose is markedly low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a feature of Von Gierke disease?

options.label: D
options.text: Crumpled tissue paper appearance of cytoplasm on Bone marrow study

questions.correct_answer: D. Crumpled tissue paper appearance of cytoplasm on Bone marrow study
questions.explanation:
Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)

Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe fasting hypoglycemia (Option B ruled out)
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperlipidemia (Option B ruled out)
  • Doll-like facies (Option C ruled out)

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)

questions.text: Which of the following is called a countercurrent exchanger?

options.label: A
options.text: Thin descending limb of Loop of Henle

options.label: B
options.text: Thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Countercurrent Multiplier

Countercurrent Exchanger EV

Function

Creates the medullary concentration gradient.

Maintains the medullary concentration gradient

Mechanism

Active transport of Na⁺, Cl⁻ (no water) → sets up osmotic gradient

Passive exchange of solutes and water via diffusion

Energy use

Requires ATP (active transport)

No ATP (passive process)

Purpose

Concentrates medullary interstitium

Prevents "washout" of medullary gradient

Main structure

Loop of Henle (especially thick ascending limb) (Option A, B ruled out)

Vasa recta (capillaries of juxtamedullary nephrons) (Option D)
